Abidjan_Cote d'Ivoire
Description: The port of Abidjan is a deep sea port in Cote d'Ivoire. It is the second most important port in Africa after the port of Durban. It contributes majorly to the economy of West Africa. It serves a number of landlocked countries such as Burkina Faso, Mali, Niger, Chad, and Guinea. It has 34 berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Industries; Local communities; City of Abidjan
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Fish; Cocoa; Timber; Coffee; Pineapple; Banana; Manganese; Vehicle spare parts; Textiles; Soap
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: Export-Import Bank of China; Bolloré Group; Maersk; Government of Côte d'Ivoire

name: Toamasina_Madagascar
Description: The Port of Toamasina is Madagascar’s main port, handling containers, dry and liquid bulk and general cargo.
Key_beneficiaries: Government of Madagascar; City of Taomasina; Local communities; Port of Mombasa; Truck driver
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Petroleum; Rice; Palm oil; Pharmaceutical products; Raw nickel; Clove; Cobalt
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: Government of Japan; World Bank

name: Beira_Mozambique
Description: The port of Beira is the second largest port in Mozambique. It is strategically located, serving some of the landlocked countries in Southern Africa, such as Zimbabwe, Malawi, Zambia, Botswana and Democratic Republic of Congo. It has 11 berths.
Key_beneficiaries: National Directorate of Ports and Railways; Farmers; Industries; Traders; Local communities; Truck drivers; Freight operators
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Crude Petroleum; Fertilisers; Wheat; Agricultural machinery; Textiles; Palm oil
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: World Bank

name: Maputo_Mozambique
Description: The port of Maputo is the main port of Mozambique. It has a significant regional potential as an important gateway to South Africa and other regional countries including Botswana, Swaziland and Zimbabwe.While 1972 the Maputo Port was a major infrastructure, but in 2003 major rehabilitation works and investments led to substantial growth of the port. It has 16 berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Freight operators; Industries; Mining companies; Local communities
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Coal; Fruit; Sugar; Steel; Molasses; Petroleum; Cereals; Aluminium; Citrus; Chromite
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: Government of Mozambique; Government of China

name: Nacala_Mozambique
Description: The port of Nacala is a deep water port located in Northern Mozambique. The port is an important access route for imports and export cargo from Malawi and Zambia.It has four berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Industries; Truck drivers; Local communities; Farmers; Zambezi Valley Development Agency; Municipal Authorities
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Coal; Cotton; Tea; Tobacco; Groundnuts; Cashew nuts; Sisal; Timber; Maize; Animal products; Vegetable oil
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: African Development Bank; Other funders (unspecified)

name: Berbera_Somalia
Description: Located 937km east of Addis Ababa, the Port of Berbera is seen by Addis Ababa as the second nearest port to serve its growing volume of cargo in addition to the congested port of Djibouti. Nearly 98 percent of Ethiopia’s import and export cargo is shuttled via port Djibouti. The port of Berbera has one 650 m wharf capable of accepting ships of up to 15 000 tonnes and a line of seven wharves, including one for RO-RO. The "Russian" wharves (400 m) were built in 1960, and the "American" ones (250 m) in 1986. There is also an oil terminal with a capacity of 30 000 tonnes, distributed among 22 tanks currently operated by Total. Storage capacity is 1200m3 .  It has five berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Somaliland Ministry of Foreign Affairs; Somaliland Port Authority; Government of Ethiopia; Government of Somaliland; Government of United Arab Emirates; Berbera Port Authority; Government of Russia; Government of United States of America
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Petroleum; Livestock; Gum Arabic; Myrrh; Frankincense
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: DP World; European Commission; Government of Ethiopia; Authority of Somaliland; Other funders (unspecified)

name: Muqdisho_Somalia
Project_name: Port of Mogadishu (or Mogadishu International Port)
Description: The Port of Mogadishu is the official seaport of Mogadishu. It is the largest harbour in the country, however, it has been facing challenges due to the wars that have been happening in the country. The port of Mogadishu has undergone a massive transformation, owing to the reduced threat of piracy and improved security, which has led to opening up of the port and increased investors’ confidence. The Port is managed by Al Bayrak, a Turkish company. Between 1991-2006, the port was closed for business as there were disagreements over who should control it. In 2006-2009, rehabilitation works allowed activity to slowly start again. In 2010 a new government was appointed, which then re-shuffled the port management and monthly revenue subsequently rose from US $0.9 million to over US $2.5 million. It has six berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Somali Port Authority; Entrepreneurs; Local communities
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Oil; Sugar; Rice; Cement; Animal products
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: African Development Bank

name: Cape Town_South Africa
Description: The Port of Cape Town is the second largest container facility in South Africa after the Port of Durban. The port is located in Table Bay in the northern end of the Cape Peninsula. The port is strategic on the South Atlantic route, one of the world’s busiest trade routes. It has 34 berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Traders; Manufacturers; Farmers; Truck drivers
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Fruit; Vehicle spare parts; Chemicals; Fertilisers; Iron; Steel; Barley; Maize
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: Government of South Africa; French Development Agency

name: Durban_South Africa
Description: The port of Durban is the busiest shipping terminal in sub Saharan Africa. It has a diverse economy with busy sectors in manufacturing, transportation, government, finance and tourism.  It has 59 berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Government of South Africa; Kwazulu Natal Department of Transport; Traders; Manufacturers; Farmers; Truck drivers
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Vehicle spare parts; Grain; Fruit; Paper; Timber; Machinery; Oil; Fish; Rice; Sugar; Wheat; Fluorspar; Chemicals; Fertilisers; Soda ash; Coal; Minerals
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: Government of South Africa; Other funders (unspecified)

name: Kamsar_Guinea
Description: The port of Kamsar is a relatively small port but an important infrastructure facilitating the transportation of bauxite from the mine located in Sangaredi. Additionally, the port helps in the transportation of petroleum products. It has two berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Mining companies; Government of Guinea; Local communities; Logistics companies
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Iron ore; Petroleum
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: NI

name: Cotonou_Benin
Description: Benin’s port of Cotonou is a potential gateway to landlocked West African countries, but high shipping costs, low efficiency, and poor logistical facilities have kept it from becoming a key trade route. In 2011, the beginning of renovation works began-expected to be completed in 2020.
Key_beneficiaries: Government of Benin; Government of Burkina Faso; Government of Mali; Government of Niger; Traders; Local communities
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Fruit; Nuts; Cotton; Copper; Fish; Animal products; Palm oil; Brewing textile; Petroleum; Bauxite; Iron; Aluminium; Cement
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: World Bank

name: Dakar_Senegal
Description: The Dakar Container Port Project is to reduce freight costs for Senegal's external trade and enhance Dakar's position as a port of transfer for neighboring countries by provision of additional facilities and rehabilitation of existing ones and by strengthening the Port's management and operations.
Key_beneficiaries: Government of Senegal; Traders; Truck drivers; Local communities; Industries
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Fish; Groundnuts; Petroleum; Phosphate; Cotton
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: World Bank

name: Dar Es Salaam_Tanzania
Description: The port of Dar es Salaam is the largest and most important port in Tanzania. It handles over 90% of the country’s cargo. It is an important gat way for cargo for the landlocked countries such as Rwanda, Burundi, Democratic republic of Congo, Zambia, Malawi and Uganda.
Key_beneficiaries: Government of Tanzania; Government of Malawi; Government of Zambia; Government of Democratic Republic of Congo; Government of Burundi; Government of Rwanda; Government of Uganda; Local communities; Traders; Fishing industries
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Sugar; Rice; Coffee; Tea; Maize; Cassava; Tobacco; Sisal; Textiles; Fish; Vehicle spare parts; Vehicle spare parts
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: World Bank; Government of Tanzania

name: Tanga_Tanzania
Description: The Tanga port is approximately 350km north of Dar es Salaam. It was the first port to be developed in Tanzania, allowing access to Arusha and Moshi. It is a small seaport in terms of land and volumes of cargo handled per annum. It has two berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Government of Tanzania; Government of Rwanda; Government of Burundi; Government of Uganda; Traders; Logistics companies
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Coffee; Tea; Sisal; Fish
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: Government of Tanzania; Government of Oman

name: Djibouti_Djibouti
Description: The port of Djibouti is strategically located at the southern entrance to the Red sea, at the intersection of major international shipping lines connecting Asia, Africa and Europe. It has four berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Logistics companies; Truck drivers; Local communities
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Crude Petroleum; Petroleum; Cereals; Fertilisers
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: Government of the United States of America; Other funders (unspecified)

name: Douala_Cameroon
Description: The port of Douala is Cameroon’s major sea port. It is located on the shores of the Wouri River estuary. It is a deep water port and it facilitates the country’s international trade. It has three berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Government of Cameroon; Traders; Local communities; Industries
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Timber; Bauxite; Banana; Wheat; Fish; Petroleum
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: NI

name: Port De Kribi_Cameroon
Description: The Kribi deepwater port is Located in the southwestern part of the Republic of Cameroon, Kribi, on the edge of the Gulf of Guinea. The Kribi deepwater port was built by China Harbour Engineering Corporation and financed through China's Exim bank.
Key_beneficiaries: Traders; Government of Cameroon; Maritime services companies; Local communities; Logistics companies
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Iron ore; Fish; Industrial goods; Timber
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: Export-Import Bank of China; Other funders (unspecified)

name: Freetown_Sierra Leone
Description: The port of Freetown is the principal commercial port in Sierra Leone. It has six berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Sierra Leone Port Authority; Bolloré Group; Local communities; Truck drivers
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Vehicle spare parts; Industrial goods; Fish
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: World Bank

name: Lamu_Kenya
Corridor_name: Lamu Port South Sudan Ethiopia Transport Corridor (LAPSSET)
Description: The Lamu port project is part of the LAPSSET project,one of the flagship infrastructure projects identified by Kenya’s development blueprint Vision 2030. The project involves the construction of 32 berths along a 6, 000m stretch at Manda bay. The construction of the first three births is the first priority while the rest will follow. Manda bay in Lamu was selected as the port area since it is well sheltered and has deep waters. It has 32 berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Lamu County government; Local communities; Traders; Fishing industries
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Vehicle spare parts; Vehicle spare parts; Maize; Rice; Fish; Textiles; Second-hand clothes
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: Government of Kenya; African Development Bank

name: Mombasa_Kenya
Description: The port of Mombasa is the main port of Kenya and has 16 deep water berths. The port serves as the main gateway to the landlocked East Africa countries such as Uganda, Rwanda, Burundi, DRC and South Sudan. A significant number of shippers now prefer to route Zanzibar cargo through Mombasa. Other interests for having Mombasa as the port of preference have also been expressed by shippers from Mogadishu. Upgrading was conducted in 2016. It has 19 berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Kenya Ports Authority; Local communities; Traders; Logistics companies; Truck drivers
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Wheat; Petroleum; Rice; Sugar; Vehicle spare parts; Cement; Textiles
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: Government of Kenya; European Investment Bank; French Development Agency
Type_of_major_donors_or_financiers: National government; Multilateral bank; International development agency

name: Port Owendo_Gabon
Project_name: Port of Owendo (or Port of Libreville)
Corridor_name: Libreville-Brazzaville-Pointe Noire Corridor (or Pointe Noire – Cabinda Corridor)
Description: The Port of Owendo is a Gabon special economic zone which is a joint venture between Olam international limited, republic of Gabon and the Africa finance corporation. Owendo Port has launched a new multi-purpose and container terminal in a ceremony on October 14, 2017. It has four berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Local communities; Port Authority of Gabon; Government of Gabon; Gabon Special Economic Zones
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Timber; Manganese; Uranium; Cocoa; Cement constituents
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: Emerging Africa Infrastructure Fund; African Development Bank
Type_of_major_donors_or_financiers: Regional economic community; Regional development bank

name: Lobito_Angola
Description: The port of Lobito lies on Angola’s coast. It connects commodity producers from the Copperbelt with international markets and is an excellent location for raw materials and imported fuel products.
Key_beneficiaries: Government of Angola; Industries; Local communities
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Sugar; Copper; Canned fish; Construction material; Crude Petroleum; Petroleum
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: Government of Angola

name: Lome_Toga
Description: The port of Lomé is the main port in Togo. It is strategically located in West Africa coast from which several cities can be reached by road in one day, offering the advantage of moving goods at a reasonable timeframe and a competitive cost. Modernization of the port took place in the 1960s. It has three berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Government of Togo; Local communities; Truck drivers
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Textiles; Vehicle spare parts; Sugar; Rice; Cotton; Shea Butter
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: African Development Bank; German Investment and Development Company; OPEC Fund for International Development
Type_of_major_donors_or_financiers: Regional development bank; National bank; International development agency

name: Luderitz Bay_Namibia
Description: The Port of Lüderitz lies south of the port of Walvis Bay along Namibia’s coastline. It provides access to markets in the Northern Cape of South Africa. It is an important base for the fishing industry and the offshore diamond and mining industries. The port was constructed in the 1800s but it is only since the new Namport administration took over in 1995 that Luderitz has begun to resurrect itself as the gateway to the south of Namibia. It is operated by the Walvis Bay Corridor Group. It has three berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Fishing industries; Diamond Mining Industries; Fruit Industry
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Fish; Diamond; Fruit
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: Government of Namibia

name: Walvis Bay_Namibia
Corridor_name: Trans-Caprivi Corridor (TCC) (or Walvis Bay-Ndola-Lumbumbashi Development Corridor (WBNLDC))
Description: The Port of Walvis Bay is Namibia's largest commercial port. It is strategically located half way down the coast of Namibia, with direct access to principal shipping routes, Walvis Bay is a natural gateway for international trade. In 1994 the port becomes managed by the public sector but there are continuous improvements and investments till the present day. It has 11 berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Oil companies; Salt Company; Mining companies; Fishing industries; Guateng Province in South Africa; Tourists; Passengers
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Salt; Petroleum; Diamond; Copper; Lead; Uranium; Livestock; Fish; Mollusc
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: Government of Namibia; African Development Bank

name: Mitsiwa Harbor_Eritrea
Description: Port of Massawa is the main port for Eritrea. The port is situated on the northern shore of Massawa island. The port was first constructed in 19th Century but an important rehabilitation took place in the period 1995-2005. It has six berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Government of Eritrea; Traders; Fishing industries; Local communities; Tourism industry; Shipping service providers; Massawa Port Authority
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Fish; Maize; Wheat; Rice; Fertilisers; Iron; Steel; Vehicle spare parts; Industrial machinery; Crude Petroleum; Salt

name: Nouakchott_Mauritania
Description: The port is strategically located at the crossroads of the routes connecting Africa, Europe and America, and is one of the leading public commercial ports in the south Sahara for ships sailing from Europe.
Key_beneficiaries: Government of the Islamic Republic of Mauritania; Traders; Freight operators; Truck drivers
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Iron ore; Gold; Copper; Gypsum; Fish; Cement; Clinker; Flour; Sugar; Petroleum

name: Point Noire_Republic of Congo
Corridor_name: Pointe Noire – Cabinda Corridor (or Libreville-Brazzaville-Pointe Noire Corridor)
Description: The Port of Pointe Noire is a large sea port in the Republic of Congo. It has four berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Government of Republic of Congo; Traders
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Crude Petroleum; Copper; Petroleum; Timber; Iron; Palm oil; Pharmaceutical products
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: NI

name: Port Sudan_Sudan
Description: The Port of Sudan is the main seaport of Sudan and handles most of the country’s external trade. It has modern docking facilities and an oil refinery. It has 16 berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Sea Ports Corporation; Entrepreneurs; Local communities; Truck drivers
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Cotton; Groundnuts; Sesame seed; Castor seed; Crude Petroleum; Construction material; Vehicle spare parts; Animal products
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: World Bank

name: Takoradi_Ghana
Description: The port is located in western Ghana, and is managed by the Ghana Ports and Harbours Authority. It is an important export port for Ghana. It has six berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Government of Ghana; Local communities; Mining Industries; Farmers; Truck drivers
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Cocoa; Timber; Bauxite; Gold; Manganese; Diamond; Vegetables
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: African Development Bank

name: Tema_Ghana
Description: The port of Tema lies on the shores of the Gulf of Guinea in Southeastern Ghana and is the largest in the country. The port is currently being upgraded and expanded to improve the port handling capacity. Construction of the port began in 1954. Regular traffic began in 1962. In 1997, the second quay began construction up to approximately 2005. In 2007 the second phase of construction of the container terminal began in a 140,000sqm container stacking area, referred to as the complexes and mechanical work shops were completed. It has 12 berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Traders; Industries; Government of Ghana; Maritime services companies
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Vehicle spare parts; Fish; Crude Petroleum; Petroleum; Rice; Sugar; Wheat; Aluminium; Clinker
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: International Finance Corporation; Bank of China

name: Victoria_Seychelles
Description: The Port of Victoria is the main port serving Seychelles and is a crucial economic pillar of Seychelles. It is an important gateway through which imports and exports of the country flow through.
Key_beneficiaries: Entrepreneurs; Truck drivers; Local communities
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Vanilla; Coconut products; Coconut products; Tortoise shell; Soap; Guano
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: European Investment Bank; French Development Agency

This is linked to the Northern Corridor.  It has four quays.

Name_of_donors_or_financiers: World Bank; Government of Eritrea; Government of Italy

Description: The Port of Assab is an important port in Eritrea that serves not only Eritrea and the horn of Africa region. It was an important trade route to Ethiopia, which is Landlocked, but ceased in 1998 due to the Eritrea-Ethiopia war. Port was constructed in the 1800s but major restoration was completed in 2012. It consists of three berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Government of Eritrea; Government of Ethiopia; Government of Djibouti; Local communities; Traders; Fishing industries
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Grain; Fertilisers; Iron; Steel; Vehicle spare parts; Salt
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: World Bank; Government of Eritrea

Description: The King Mswati III International Airport is Eswatini’s flagship facility in the nationwide infrastructural investment to facilitate economic growth to a first world status level.
Key_beneficiaries: Government of South Africa; Entrepreneurs; Eswatini Game Parks; Kruger National Park; Maputo National Reserve; Kwazulu Natal Game Reserves; Tourism industry; Tourists; Entrepreneurs
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Passengers
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: Government of Eswatini; Government of Taiwan

Project_name: Port of Owendo (or Port of Libreville)
Corridor_name: Libreville-Brazzaville-Pointe Noire Corridor (or Pointe Noire – Cabinda Corridor)
Description: The Port of Owendo is a Gabon special economic zone which is a joint venture between Olam international limited, republic of Gabon and the Africa finance corporation. Owendo Port has launched a new multi-purpose and container terminal in a ceremony on October 14, 2017. It has four berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Local communities; Port Authority of Gabon; Government of Gabon; Gabon Special Economic Zones
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Timber; Manganese; Uranium; Cocoa; Cement constituents
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: Emerging Africa Infrastructure Fund; African Development Bank
Type_of_major_donors_or_financiers: Regional economic community; Regional development bank

Description: The port of Tema lies on the shores of the Gulf of Guinea in Southeastern Ghana and is the largest in the country. The port is currently being upgraded and expanded to improve the port handling capacity. Construction of the port began in 1954. Regular traffic began in 1962. In 1997, the second quay began construction up to approximately 2005. In 2007 the second phase of construction of the container terminal began in a 140,000sqm container stacking area, referred to as the complexes and mechanical work shops were completed. It has 12 berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Traders; Industries; Government of Ghana; Maritime services companies
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Vehicle spare parts; Fish; Crude Petroleum; Petroleum; Rice; Sugar; Wheat; Aluminium; Clinker
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: International Finance Corporation; Bank of China

Description: The port of Conakry is one of the key ports in Guinea and handles refined petroleum oil and crude petroleum oil and general cargo. It has two berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Government of Guinea; Industries; Traders; Logistics companies
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Vehicle spare parts; Rice; Sugar; Aluminium
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: Emerging Africa Infrastructure Fund; World Bank; Other funders (unspecified)
Type_of_major_donors_or_financiers: Regional development agency; Multilateral bank; NI

Description: The port of Mombasa is the main port of Kenya and has 16 deep water berths. The port serves as the main gateway to the landlocked East Africa countries such as Uganda, Rwanda, Burundi, DRC and South Sudan. A significant number of shippers now prefer to route Zanzibar cargo through Mombasa. Other interests for having Mombasa as the port of preference have also been expressed by shippers from Mogadishu. Upgrading was conducted in 2016. It has 19 berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Kenya Ports Authority; Local communities; Traders; Logistics companies; Truck drivers
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Wheat; Petroleum; Rice; Sugar; Vehicle spare parts; Cement; Textiles
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: Government of Kenya; European Investment Bank; French Development Agency
Type_of_major_donors_or_financiers: National government; Multilateral bank; International development agency

Description: The Port of Toamasina is Madagascar’s main port, handling containers, dry and liquid bulk and general cargo.
Key_beneficiaries: Government of Madagascar; City of Taomasina; Local communities; Port of Mombasa; Truck driver
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Petroleum; Rice; Palm oil; Pharmaceutical products; Raw nickel; Clove; Cobalt
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: Government of Japan; World Bank

Description: The port is strategically located at the crossroads of the routes connecting Africa, Europe and America, and is one of the leading public commercial ports in the south Sahara for ships sailing from Europe.
Key_beneficiaries: Government of the Islamic Republic of Mauritania; Traders; Freight operators; Truck drivers
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Iron ore; Gold; Copper; Gypsum; Fish; Cement; Clinker; Flour; Sugar; Petroleum
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: Africa Finance Corporation; World Bank; Government of the Islamic Republic of Mauritania
Type_of_major_donors_or_financiers: Regional development bank; Multilateral bank; National government

Description: The port of Maputo is the main port of Mozambique. It has a significant regional potential as an important gateway to South Africa and other regional countries including Botswana, Swaziland and Zimbabwe.While 1972 the Maputo Port was a major infrastructure, but in 2003 major rehabilitation works and investments led to substantial growth of the port. It has 16 berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Freight operators; Industries; Mining companies; Local communities
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Coal; Fruit; Sugar; Steel; Molasses; Petroleum; Cereals; Aluminium; Citrus; Chromite
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: Government of Mozambique; Government of China

Corridor_name: Trans-Caprivi Corridor (TCC) (or Walvis Bay-Ndola-Lumbumbashi Development Corridor (WBNLDC))
Description: The Port of Walvis Bay is Namibia's largest commercial port. It is strategically located half way down the coast of Namibia, with direct access to principal shipping routes, Walvis Bay is a natural gateway for international trade. In 1994 the port becomes managed by the public sector but there are continuous improvements and investments till the present day. It has 11 berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Oil companies; Salt Company; Mining companies; Fishing industries; Guateng Province in South Africa; Tourists; Passengers
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Salt; Petroleum; Diamond; Copper; Lead; Uranium; Livestock; Fish; Mollusc
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: Government of Namibia; African Development Bank

Description: The Port of Lüderitz lies south of the port of Walvis Bay along Namibia’s coastline. It provides access to markets in the Northern Cape of South Africa. It is an important base for the fishing industry and the offshore diamond and mining industries. The port was constructed in the 1800s but it is only since the new Namport administration took over in 1995 that Luderitz has begun to resurrect itself as the gateway to the south of Namibia. It is operated by the Walvis Bay Corridor Group. It has three berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Fishing industries; Diamond Mining Industries; Fruit Industry
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Fish; Diamond; Fruit
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: Government of Namibia

Description: The Port of Victoria is the main port serving Seychelles and is a crucial economic pillar of Seychelles. It is an important gateway through which imports and exports of the country flow through.
Key_beneficiaries: Entrepreneurs; Truck drivers; Local communities
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Vanilla; Coconut products; Coconut products; Tortoise shell; Soap; Guano
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: European Investment Bank; French Development Agency
Type_of_major_donors_or_financiers: Regional development bank; International development agency

Description: The port of Freetown is the principal commercial port in Sierra Leone. It has six berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Sierra Leone Port Authority; Bolloré Group; Local communities; Truck drivers
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Vehicle spare parts; Industrial goods; Fish
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: World Bank

Project_name: Port of Mogadishu (or Mogadishu International Port)
Description: The Port of Mogadishu is the official seaport of Mogadishu. It is the largest harbour in the country, however, it has been facing challenges due to the wars that have been happening in the country. The port of Mogadishu has undergone a massive transformation, owing to the reduced threat of piracy and improved security, which has led to opening up of the port and increased investors’ confidence. The Port is managed by Al Bayrak, a Turkish company. Between 1991-2006, the port was closed for business as there were disagreements over who should control it. In 2006-2009, rehabilitation works allowed activity to slowly start again. In 2010 a new government was appointed, which then re-shuffled the port management and monthly revenue subsequently rose from US $0.9 million to over US $2.5 million. It has six berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Somali Port Authority; Entrepreneurs; Local communities
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Oil; Sugar; Rice; Cement; Animal products
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: African Development Bank

Description: The port of Durban is the busiest shipping terminal in sub Saharan Africa. It has a diverse economy with busy sectors in manufacturing, transportation, government, finance and tourism.  It has 59 berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Government of South Africa; Kwazulu Natal Department of Transport; Traders; Manufacturers; Farmers; Truck drivers
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Vehicle spare parts; Grain; Fruit; Paper; Timber; Machinery; Oil; Fish; Rice; Sugar; Wheat; Fluorspar; Chemicals; Fertilisers; Soda ash; Coal; Minerals
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: Government of South Africa; Other funders (unspecified)

Description: The Port of Sudan is the main seaport of Sudan and handles most of the country’s external trade. It has modern docking facilities and an oil refinery. It has 16 berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Sea Ports Corporation; Entrepreneurs; Local communities; Truck drivers
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Cotton; Groundnuts; Sesame seed; Castor seed; Crude Petroleum; Construction material; Vehicle spare parts; Animal products
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: World Bank

Description: The port of Dar es Salaam is the largest and most important port in Tanzania. It handles over 90% of the country’s cargo. It is an important gat way for cargo for the landlocked countries such as Rwanda, Burundi, Democratic republic of Congo, Zambia, Malawi and Uganda.
Key_beneficiaries: Government of Tanzania; Government of Malawi; Government of Zambia; Government of Democratic Republic of Congo; Government of Burundi; Government of Rwanda; Government of Uganda; Local communities; Traders; Fishing industries
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Sugar; Rice; Coffee; Tea; Maize; Cassava; Tobacco; Sisal; Textiles; Fish; Vehicle spare parts; Vehicle spare parts
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: World Bank; Government of Tanzania

Description: The port of Lomé is the main port in Togo. It is strategically located in West Africa coast from which several cities can be reached by road in one day, offering the advantage of moving goods at a reasonable timeframe and a competitive cost. Modernization of the port took place in the 1960s. It has three berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Government of Togo; Local communities; Truck drivers
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Textiles; Vehicle spare parts; Sugar; Rice; Cotton; Shea Butter
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: African Development Bank; German Investment and Development Company; OPEC Fund for International Development
Type_of_major_donors_or_financiers: Regional development bank; National bank; International development agency

Description: The port of Beira is the second largest port in Mozambique. It is strategically located, serving some of the landlocked countries in Southern Africa, such as Zimbabwe, Malawi, Zambia, Botswana and Democratic Republic of Congo. It has 11 berths.
Key_beneficiaries: National Directorate of Ports and Railways; Farmers; Industries; Traders; Local communities; Truck drivers; Freight operators
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Crude Petroleum; Fertilisers; Wheat; Agricultural machinery; Textiles; Palm oil
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: World Bank

Description: The Kribi deepwater port is Located in the southwestern part of the Republic of Cameroon, Kribi, on the edge of the Gulf of Guinea. The Kribi deepwater port was built by China Harbour Engineering Corporation and financed through China's Exim bank.
Key_beneficiaries: Traders; Government of Cameroon; Maritime services companies; Local communities; Logistics companies
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Iron ore; Fish; Industrial goods; Timber
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: Export-Import Bank of China; Other funders (unspecified)

Corridor_name: Lamu Port South Sudan Ethiopia Transport Corridor (LAPSSET)
Description: The Lamu port project is part of the LAPSSET project,one of the flagship infrastructure projects identified by Kenya’s development blueprint Vision 2030. The project involves the construction of 32 berths along a 6, 000m stretch at Manda bay. The construction of the first three births is the first priority while the rest will follow. Manda bay in Lamu was selected as the port area since it is well sheltered and has deep waters. It has 32 berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Lamu County government; Local communities; Traders; Fishing industries
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Vehicle spare parts; Vehicle spare parts; Maize; Rice; Fish; Textiles; Second-hand clothes
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: Government of Kenya; African Development Bank

Description: The existing Mtwara port will be expanded, to allow for an export-processing zone. This will help improve the regional economy and increase revenue from the port. In June 2020, the construction was at 55% of implementation.
Key_beneficiaries: Government of Tanzania; Mtwara Communities; Traders; Bangote Cement Factory
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Cashew nuts; Petroleum; Vehicle spare parts; Sugar; Salt; Rice; Beverages
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: Government of Tanzania; Government of Finland

Description: The port of Abidjan is a deep sea port in Cote d'Ivoire. It is the second most important port in Africa after the port of Durban. It contributes majorly to the economy of West Africa. It serves a number of landlocked countries such as Burkina Faso, Mali, Niger, Chad, and Guinea. It has 34 berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Industries; Local communities; City of Abidjan
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Fish; Cocoa; Timber; Coffee; Pineapple; Banana; Manganese; Vehicle spare parts; Textiles; Soap
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: Export-Import Bank of China; Bolloré Group; Maersk; Government of Côte d'Ivoire

Description: The Dakar Container Port Project is to reduce freight costs for Senegal's external trade and enhance Dakar's position as a port of transfer for neighboring countries by provision of additional facilities and rehabilitation of existing ones and by strengthening the Port's management and operations.
Key_beneficiaries: Government of Senegal; Traders; Truck drivers; Local communities; Industries
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Fish; Groundnuts; Petroleum; Phosphate; Cotton
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: World Bank

Description: The port is located in western Ghana, and is managed by the Ghana Ports and Harbours Authority. It is an important export port for Ghana. It has six berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Government of Ghana; Local communities; Mining Industries; Farmers; Truck drivers
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Cocoa; Timber; Bauxite; Gold; Manganese; Diamond; Vegetables
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: African Development Bank

Description: The Tanga port is approximately 350km north of Dar es Salaam. It was the first port to be developed in Tanzania, allowing access to Arusha and Moshi. It is a small seaport in terms of land and volumes of cargo handled per annum. It has two berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Government of Tanzania; Government of Rwanda; Government of Burundi; Government of Uganda; Traders; Logistics companies
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Coffee; Tea; Sisal; Fish
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: Government of Tanzania; Government of Oman

Description: Located 937km east of Addis Ababa, the Port of Berbera is seen by Addis Ababa as the second nearest port to serve its growing volume of cargo in addition to the congested port of Djibouti. Nearly 98 percent of Ethiopia’s import and export cargo is shuttled via port Djibouti. The port of Berbera has one 650 m wharf capable of accepting ships of up to 15 000 tonnes and a line of seven wharves, including one for RO-RO. The "Russian" wharves (400 m) were built in 1960, and the "American" ones (250 m) in 1986. There is also an oil terminal with a capacity of 30 000 tonnes, distributed among 22 tanks currently operated by Total. Storage capacity is 1200m3 .  It has five berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Somaliland Ministry of Foreign Affairs; Somaliland Port Authority; Government of Ethiopia; Government of Somaliland; Government of United Arab Emirates; Berbera Port Authority; Government of Russia; Government of United States of America
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Petroleum; Livestock; Gum Arabic; Myrrh; Frankincense
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: DP World; European Commission; Government of Ethiopia; Authority of Somaliland; Other funders (unspecified)

Description: The Port of Cape Town is the second largest container facility in South Africa after the Port of Durban. The port is located in Table Bay in the northern end of the Cape Peninsula. The port is strategic on the South Atlantic route, one of the world’s busiest trade routes. It has 34 berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Traders; Manufacturers; Farmers; Truck drivers
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Fruit; Vehicle spare parts; Chemicals; Fertilisers; Iron; Steel; Barley; Maize
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: Government of South Africa; French Development Agency

Description: The port of Nacala is a deep water port located in Northern Mozambique. The port is an important access route for imports and export cargo from Malawi and Zambia.It has four berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Industries; Truck drivers; Local communities; Farmers; Zambezi Valley Development Agency; Municipal Authorities
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Coal; Cotton; Tea; Tobacco; Groundnuts; Cashew nuts; Sisal; Timber; Maize; Animal products; Vegetable oil
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: African Development Bank; Other funders (unspecified)

Description: The port of Djibouti is strategically located at the southern entrance to the Red sea, at the intersection of major international shipping lines connecting Asia, Africa and Europe. It has four berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Logistics companies; Truck drivers; Local communities
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Crude Petroleum; Petroleum; Cereals; Fertilisers
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: Government of the United States of America; Other funders (unspecified)

Description: The port of Kamsar is a relatively small port but an important infrastructure facilitating the transportation of bauxite from the mine located in Sangaredi. Additionally, the port helps in the transportation of petroleum products. It has two berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Mining companies; Government of Guinea; Local communities; Logistics companies
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Iron ore; Petroleum
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: NI

Corridor_name: Pointe Noire – Cabinda Corridor (or Libreville-Brazzaville-Pointe Noire Corridor)
Description: The Port of Pointe Noire is a large sea port in the Republic of Congo. It has four berths.
Key_beneficiaries: Government of Republic of Congo; Traders
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Crude Petroleum; Copper; Petroleum; Timber; Iron; Palm oil; Pharmaceutical products
Name_of_donors_or_financiers: NI

Description: The port of Cabinda is located in the city of Cabinda and an important gateway to the coutry for imports. The port will boost trade between Angola and the rest of Africa and beyond. It has one berth.
Key_beneficiaries: Government of Republic of Congo; Oil companies; Entrepreneurs
Commodities_traded_or_transported: Crude Petroleum; Building material; Fish; Sugar
